Waypoints.Name: Layers of the Heart Wall
Waypoints.Description:
The first organ to form during fetal development, the heart 
is responsible for pumping blood through the circulatory system
to supply oxygen to all cells of the body. In humans, the heart is 
located in the chest cavity between the lungs and sits in a fuild-filled sac
called the pericardium which serves to protect this vital organ.

The heart wall is comprised of three layers`:` the 
1) epicardium, 2) myocardium, and the 3) endocardium.

The epicardium is the outer most layer and is contiguous with the visceral
layer of the pericardium. It is composed primarily of adipose tissue, connective 
tissue including elastic fibers, and mesothelium, which secrete pericardial fluid 
to help lubricate the heart and reduce friction as it expands in volume.
The epicardium also contains coronary blood vessels that supply blood to the heart wall.

The middle layer, or the myocardium, is composed of cardiac muscle 
fibers (cardiomyocytes) that generate the contractile force 
needed to pump blood. These contractions are signaled by the peripheral 
nervous system and synchronized by Purkinje fibers. The myocardium 
is the thickest layer of the heart wall, with its thickness varying
in different parts of the heart. The myocardium of the left ventricle
is the thickest as this ventricle is responsible for generating 
enough power to pump blood through the aorta to the rest of the body. 
On average, an adult heart pumps ~6000-75000 liters of blood daily.

The endocardium is the innermost layer of the heart wall. It lines the 
inside of chambers and the valves with a simple squamous epithelium, 
or a single layer of flat cells. This type of epithelium enables rapid 
diffusion of small molecules.

In this view of the lateral left ventricle wall, epicardial fat is seen on one 
side of the section and papillary muscles present on the opposite side which 
is the left ventricle lumen.

Waypoints.Name: Papillary Muscle
Waypoints.Description:
The ventricles of the heart contain papillary muscles that attach to 
atrioventricular valves and contract to prevent inversion of the valves 
and backflow of blood during systole.

In the center of one of the papillary muscles is a region of acute ischemia 
with mildly increased eosinophilia (approximately 12-24 hours). 

Peripherally, there is a layer of 5-8 myocytes that are viable but vacuolated. 
These myocytes are alive because of their proximity to the ventricular lumen 
where the blood pumping through the heart provides for the metabolic needs so 
as to prevent infarction and death of those peripherally located cells. 

Often, when there is infarction of the papillary muscles of the left ventricle 
which anchor the mitral valve leaflets via the chordae tendineae, there is 
mitral valve dysfunction and prominent regurgitation that can result in rapid 
back flow of blood down the low hemodynamic pressure of the left atrium, and 
the left veins into the lung. The result is flash pulmonary edema with a rapid 
accumulation of fluid in the pulmonary interstitium and emergent respiratory distress.
